outcome.outcome_text: Analyze and establish effective strategies of support for purposes of helping others increase health-enhancing behaviours.

indicator.p: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about support strategies.
Describe the benefits one receives from helping others.
Examine the functions of support persons and networks.
Compare informal and formal community supports and how to access them.
Compare past and present examples (including traditional First Nations and Métis cultures) of how people support/supported the health of others.
Determine the traits and skills of an effective support person.
Assess personal aptitudes for supporting others.
Analyze personal preferences for receiving support.
Recognize times and situations in which others might appreciate help.
Discuss concepts such as learned dependence and empowerment or “helping others to help themselves”.
Distinguish between help that supports greater independence and that which creates dependence.

outcome.outcome_text: Analyze how personal prejudices/biases, and habits of mind shape assumptions about family identities, structures, roles, and responsibilities.

indicator.p: Describe a variety of family structures (e.g., nuclear, mixed, childless, foster, same-sex, single parent, extended).
Examine family member roles and how they are established.
Analyze gender roles that exist in many families.
Examine the family responsibilities associated with family roles.
Explore the expectations that parents/caregivers and children/youth have of one another.
Analyze personal beliefs about family structures, roles, and responsibilities.
Examine the prejudices/biases that exist in the community.
Investigate how the differences that exist in families are respected and protected in Canadian human rights legislation.
Examine how prejudices/biases are learned attitudes and behaviours.
Recognize, name, and challenge instances of inequity, bias, intolerance, and discrimination related to family identities, structures, roles, and responsibilities.
Reflect on personal prejudices and their influences on assumptions about families.
Analyze how stereotyping and social constructions (e.g., gender, “poor bashing”, white privilege) affect the well-being of self, family, and community.
Question examples of injustice towards families in own communities.

outcome.outcome_text: Investigate and analyze the impact of in/formal supports and services (including testing/diagnostic services) available to individuals, families, and communities infected with/affected by non-curable infections/diseases (including HIV and Hepatitis C).

indicator.p: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about the supports needed/wanted by individuals, families, and communities infected with/affected by non-curable infections/diseases (including HIV and Hepatitis C).
Describe the effects of non-curable infections/diseases, including HIV and Hepatitis on families and communities.
Explore the consequences of having/not having supports (both formal and informal) for self, family, and community.

Recognize that some non-curable infections, including HIV, are linked to risky behaviours and not to particular groups of people, and use this knowledge to determine when people should be tested for HIV.
Explore the recommended follow-up procedures and supports for those who test positive for the HI virus.
Describe how misinformation and/or lack of understanding may influence the kinds of supports available to people infected with/affected by non-curable infections.
Investigate and critique the kinds of supports needed to mitigate some of the behaviours associated with acquiring non-curable infections/diseases (e.g., needle exchanges, safer sex practices).
Examine the types of informal and formal community supports available for people infected and/or affected by non-curable infections/diseases, including HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C.
Investigate sources of and information about testing for HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C.
Consider the impact that education has on the kinds of supports available in communities for people infected with/affected by non-curable infections.
Discuss HIV testing as a support service.

outcome.outcome_text: Demonstrate an understanding of the impact of violence (including but not limited to emotional abuse, physical abuse, sexual abuse, spiritual abuse, and neglect) on the well-being of and the supports needed for self, family, and community.

indicator.p: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about violence and abuse in families and communities.
Discuss common definitions of “abuse” and “violence” and develop informed personal definitions of both.
Assess the impact of physical, emotional, spiritual, and sexual abuse on families and communities.
Determine that age does not protect one from abuse (e.g., parental, spousal, child, elder abuse).
Discuss the factors that are known to contribute to abuse (e.g., stress, exposure to violence, addictions, mental health issues, poverty).
Discuss the “cycle of abuse”.
Demonstrate ways to support those who may be experiencing abuse or living with an abusive family member.
Examine why victims of abuse sometimes keep the abuse a secret, and analyze the impact that these “secrets” have on self, family, and community.
Determine that a victim of violence/abuse is never at fault or to blame for the abuse.
Examine threats to personal safety and well-being at home, school, or in the community.
Research sources of support for and ways of protecting oneself and others from abuse.
Examine historical factors that may contribute to the disharmony within individuals, families, and communities.
Investigate sources of help for young people who behave in violent ways.
Investigate sources of help for an abused child, an abused peer, an abused parent/spouse, an abused grandparent/elder, or a family who has a mixture of violent behaviours.

outcome.outcome_text: Assess how body image satisfaction/dissatisfaction and over-reliance on appearance as a source of identity and self-esteem affects the quality of life of self and family.

indicator.p: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about healthy weights, body image, and self-esteem.
Investigate and evaluate common adolescent and adult eating and exercise habits.
Determine reasons for specific eating and/or exercise habits/patterns (e.g., time, access, preferences, allergies).
Evaluate personal habits and practices that influence body image satisfaction (e.g., clothing, tanning, piercings).
Discuss body image to include one’s feelings, attitudes, and perceptions towards his/her body and physical appearance.
Investigate the motivations for and the consequences of being satisfied or dissatisfied with how we look.

Explore the different attitudes and behaviours related to self-perception (e.g., body image satisfaction, body image investment, body image behaviour, body image perception) and how difficulties in one or all of these areas creates disturbances in body image.
Understand the pressures/influences that promote unrealistic images of desirable body shape and weight.
Analyze the relationships between self-esteem and body image.
Analyze techniques used by industries (e.g., plastic surgery, weight loss products, diets) and the mass media to influence judgement and values about the way we look.

outcome.outcome_text: Examine and assess the concept of sustainability from many perspectives, and develop an understanding of its implications for the well-being of self, others, and the environment.

indicator.p: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about sustainability.
Investigate the connections between the health of the environment and the health of people.
Examine and appreciate the ways natural environments meet physical, aesthetic, and spiritual needs.
Examine practices and activities that pose a threat to the environment and to the health of people.
Question family and community norms and expectations regarding caring for the environment.
Analyze rules, regulations, and laws related to environmental health and the health of individuals.
Analyze how one’s behaviour related to the concept of sustainability, might affect the well-being of others and other things.
Consider the kinds of changes needed to protect the environment and the health of people.
Evaluate three or more examples of perceptions on what is believed to be healthy/sustainable for the environment (i.e., examine local and provincial perspectives).
Investigate past and present practices that focus/focused on sustainability for the health of people and the environment.
Investigate social action groups/networks that exist to protect the environment and to support people in achieving optimal health.
Discuss contributions of traditional First Nations and Métis people to environmental health.

outcome.outcome_text: Assess the social, cultural, and environmental influences on and supports for sexual health knowledge, attitudes, behaviours, and decisions.

indicator.p: Compare the perceived and actual sexual attitudes/norms in the community.
Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about sexual health.
Examine influences that shape community norms about sexual health.
Compare sexual attitudes/norms of adults to those of youth in the community.
Determine the possible consequences of not knowing and questioning community attitudes/norms.
Examine how the social, cultural, and environmental influences may determine people’s knowledge and access to sexual health information.
Examine and develop an understanding of influences on responsible sexual health decisions (e.g., family, culture, social, religion).
Appraise the strategies of personal commitment (see grade 7) that are required to commit to one’s standards and to respond to the social, cultural, and environmental influences.
Analyze ways to support others and their dignity in decisions related to sexual health.
Analyze sexual health supports and services in the community.
Determine how access to sexual health supports and services influence personal and community sexual health.

outcome.outcome_text: Appraise the role of “support” in making healthy decisions related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

indicator.p: Review the kinds of support that one may need when making healthy decisions.
Critique the various kinds of support.
Discuss ways to determine when support is needed.
Distinguish between wanting and needing support.
Examine the implications or consequences of support strategies.
Recognize the kinds of support that may be needed at various stages/steps when making decisions.
Describe the influencing factors on providing and receiving support.

outcome.outcome_text: Analyze the health opportunities and challenges, and establish “support others” personal goal statements, related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

indicator.p: Assess current skills and abilities to be a support person.
Examine possible health opportunities and health challenges related to each unit of study. Discuss and evaluate various al
ternatives to address health opportunities/challenges.
Examine factors that affect the support one may give or receive.
Design a personal goal statement that supports others in each unit of study.
Determine strategies for meeting individual “support” goals.
Predict the consequences of such strategies.
Establish multiple and authentic supports in planning for healthy decision making.

outcome.outcome_text: Design, implement, and evaluate three seven-day action plans that establish multiple supports for responsible health action related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

indicator.p: Determine the elements of effective “support” action plans (e.g., who, what, where, when, how, why).
Plan the required steps to complete action plans that support others.
Identify criteria and use them to assess the design elements of “supporting others” action plans.
Distinguish, with others, criteria to evaluate the implementation of “supporting others” action plans.
Identify and use criteria to evaluate growth in one’s ability to establish supports for health.
